docs.snippet: A Q. & A. with the Oscar-nominated team for sound design and mixing in "Inception," who talk about Christopher Nolan's emotional approach to his work and his unique resistance to looping....
docs.lead_paragraph: As the Bagger discovered last season, it's almost impossible for even the Academy's experts to predict who will win the Oscars for sound design and mixing. But over the weekend, the sound team from "Inception" won Baftas from the British Academy of Film and Television Arts , and the group -- sound designer Richard King, recording mixer Ed Novick and re-recording mixer Gary Rizzo, along with his partner Lora Hirschberg -- have been talked up all season long for their work on Christopher Nolan's film, for which they are all nominated for Oscars. Creating a soundtrack for his multilevel dreamscape thriller involved technical and creative challenges born of multiple locations and complicated storytelling.
docs.abstract: A Q. & A. with the Oscar-nominated team for sound design and mixing in "Inception," who talk about Christopher Nolan's emotional approach to his work and his unique resistance to looping.

docs.snippet: Thanks to theatrical and iTunes distribution, more people are seeing Oscar-nominated short films....
docs.lead_paragraph: And in the category of surefire Oscar pool-killers, let us now examine the short films - live action, animated and documentary. Come on, cop to it: when it comes to this group in your office ballot, who hasn't just circled the movie that seems to be about the Holocaust? ("Rabbit à la Berlin" - that's close enough, right?)
docs.abstract: Thanks to theatrical and iTunes distribution, more people are seeing Oscar-nominated short films.

headline.main: The Oscar Shorts Display Box-Office Prowess

docs.snippet: On Feb. 27, Oscar Sunday, we are inaugurating a new monthly feature, allowing readers to quiz The New York Times's chief film critics....
docs.lead_paragraph: On Feb. 27, Oscar Sunday, we are inaugurating a new monthly feature called "Ask the Critics." It's just what it sounds like: a chance for readers to ask us, the New York Times chief film critics, anything (well, almost anything) having to do with film, criticism or anything else that's on your mind.
docs.abstract: On Feb. 27, Oscar Sunday, we are inaugurating a new monthly feature, allowing readers to quiz The New York Times's chief film critics.

docs.snippet: LOS ANGELES - Arnold Schwarzenegger, no longer the governor of California, told his Twitter followers on Thursday that he was back in the film business and looking for offers.     How Hollywood will welcome Mr. Schwarzenegger, now 63, is anyone's ...
docs.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES - Arnold Schwarzenegger, no longer the governor of California, told his Twitter followers on Thursday that he was back in the film business and looking for offers. How Hollywood will welcome Mr. Schwarzenegger, now 63, is anyone's guess. But he will find much has changed since he left the movies in 2003.
docs.abstract: Media Decoder blog notes former California governor Arnold Schwarzenegger tells his Twitter followers he is back in film business and looking for offers (S)
